content.description:
Start up easy climbing trending right under an overhang with a blank looking section of wall above with a bolt in the middle. Clip the bolt and pull past the overhang that seems daunting for the grade.

Just left of the right facing corner that spans the length of the wall.
5 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Great first multi-pitch for a new leader. 

P1, 5.6 (15m): Hike up a couple meters to the base of the obvious gully with bolts, pull on a couple face moves to get into it and follow the bolt line up to a bolted belay, however I would recommend linking pitches 1 and 2. 

P2, 5.6 (a couple moves) (15m): From the two bolts at the end of pitch 1 move right into the gully where there is a cable attached to bolts for 5 meters and simply walk along the gully floor until you get to a bolt above you and to the left. Chimney up to the bolt or pull on some face moves, get past it and right to the bolted belay station (ignore the rap station above and to the left). Not worth doing as it's own pitch as it's mostly just walking.

P3, 5.7 (30m): The actual climbing. Climb up and around a tree above you following the bolt line to a few more vertical moves left of a left facing corner. Top out to a bolted belay station. Walk off (recommended) or make two 30 meter rappels (first one to the rap station you ignored at the top of P2).

Furthest right climb in the area in the gully, marked with a plaque at the base.
Bolts the whole way, 12 QDs is more than enough.

Climb onto a ledge, make one 10a move up to a second ledge to bolts right of a tree.

The 4th bolt line from the left.
4 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Climb up to a ledge, then make a couple crimp moves to a matching crimp just under the second ledge, pull the ledge to make it past the crux.

5th bolt line from the left.
7 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Climb onto a ledge and pull on to sustained thin crimps and sidepulls for a few moves until you can throw out a hand to get onto the arete where the climbing eases off for an easy finish.

7th bolted line from the left.
4 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Fun slabby corner climbing.

Second route from the right, in the corner left of Cedar City (plaque).
4 bolts to a bolted anchor.

A short but burly climb. Follow a series of good underclinging flakes up to a crux at the 4th bolt.

Just as the crag veers around the corner you'll find this climb with obvious flakes on a small vertical section rock. Find the plaque at the bottom to confirm.
4 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Start in an open corner and work your way up some slabby moves with technical feet. Pull past the crux and move left to the final bolt before the anchor.

Marked with a plaque as "Freya and Cora's Delight 5.6", just right of the tree.
5 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Easy climbing up until the 3rd bolt where you make an awkward long reach for a layback into the crack, followed by some big juggy moves to a large sloping ledge. Pull on some not confidence inducing slopers and use high feet near the top to get to the anchor.

6th bolt line from the left.
6 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Make an awkward couple moves to gain the first bolt followed by easier climbing. Make a few layback style moves (cool for the grade) to get under the anchor bolts with a couple hard moves right under them to finish.

Plaque under the climb says this is 5.10b but it is easier than the 5.9 next to it, and is in line with the 5.8 grading found in Sport Climbs in the Canadian Rockies 7th Edition.

Metal plaque indicates the start of this route, just right of Drop Shot. Plaque has the right side as 5.9 (referring to Live Wire) and this route as 5.10b on the left.
5 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Start right of the large freestanding block and belay right under the tree next to it. Make easy moves up broken rock to a couple more thought provoking moves and it's over at an awkward anchor.

Right of the freestanding block in front of the tree right next to it.
5 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Easy climbing up a right facing corner onto good ledges followed by a couple thought provoking moves under a left facing and slightly overhanging corner. Pull over the corner on good holds to the top.

9th bolted line from the top. This one doesn't have a little plaque at the bottom indicating the name and grade. It is just right of the named "High Five" climb.
7 bolts to the bolted anchor.

Climb past the first bolt to a small section of blank rock with a hard move for the grade at the second bolt, continue up past large ledges to the anchor.

Just right of Live Wire which is the obvious right facing corner.
3 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Follow an ambling bolt line slightly right before returning left and to the anchor.



First bolted line to the right of the 5 unknown (short) bolted lines

Bolted with bolted anchor

Fun friction slab climbing up a few bolts gets you to a blank section of rock. Veer left on easier terrain and up to the anchor.

3rd bolted line from the right.
4 bolts to a bolted anchor.

A very easy climb following a scrambly corner feature. Most people ignore the comically low first bolt. A good first lead just to practice lead mechanics as the climbing is straightforward for the grade.

Plaque says "Unknown 5.6", at the corner where the crag starts to veer uphill.
5 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Slabby climbing up 4 bolts.

5 bolted line from the right.
4 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Scramble up the ledge to a high first bolt. Thin holds at the second bolt get you to an insecure move up onto the ledge and finish.

3rd bolted line from the left.
3 bolts to a bolted anchor

Move up and to the right on the obvious ledge system past 3 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Right of the "Unknown 5.5" route with a plaque.
3 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Climb directly up through broken rock with limited holds



Continue up the drainage past Cedar City (the last route with a plaque under it and in guide books). Approximately 15m past this climb a trail heads sharply up and left, with the first routes encountered being 5 shorter bolted lines ~10m each (5.11a, 5.10c, 5.10a, 5.9, 5.8). 

This is the first bolted line from the left of these five climbs.

Bolted with bolted anchor

Climb up through broken rock



Continue up the drainage past Cedar City (the last route with a plaque under it and in guide books). Approximately 15m past this climb a trail heads sharply up and left, with the first routes encountered being 5 shorter bolted lines ~10m each (5.11a, 5.10c, 5.10a, 5.9, 5.8). 

This is the second bolted line from the left of these five climbs.

Bolted with bolted anchor

Climb up good rock with flakes on right side. 



Continue up the drainage past Cedar City (the last route with a plaque under it and in guide books). Approximately 15m past this climb a trail heads sharply up and left, with the first routes encountered being 5 shorter bolted lines ~10m each (5.11a, 5.10c, 5.10a, 5.9, 5.8). 

This is the third bolted line from the left of these five climbs. 

Bolted with bolted anchor

Climb up through nice rock before trending to the right after the last bolt to the anchor. 



Continue up the drainage past Cedar City (the last route with a plaque under it and in guide books). Approximately 15m past this climb a trail heads sharply up and left, with the first routes encountered being 5 shorter bolted lines ~10m each (5.11a, 5.10c, 5.10a, 5.9, 5.8). 

This is the fourth bolted line from the left of these five climbs.

Bolted with bolted anchor

Climb up through good quality rock to a near anchor



Continue up the drainage past Cedar City (the last route with a plaque under it and in guide books). Approximately 15m past this climb a trail heads sharply up and left, with the first routes encountered being 5 shorter bolted lines ~10m each (5.11a, 5.10c, 5.10a, 5.9, 5.8). 

This is the fifth bolted line from the left of these five climbs.

Bolted with bolted anchor

The first route encountered on the left as you approach the crag.

Climb up onto a ledge, clip a couple bolts and make an awkwardly tough move for the grade onto another ledge and to the anchor.

First route from the left at the crag.
3 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Easily scramble up the ledge to a couple bolts on the fairly blank section of rock. Figure out a fairly insecure crux with a high clip and then walk it out to the chains.

Not recommended for a sub 5.10 leader as you could deck into the lower ledge fairly easily if you blow the 3rd clip. 

Second bolted line from the left.
4 bolts to a bolted anchor.

A small area on Mount Baldy on the west side, not as popular and developed as the Barrier Bluffs (also on Mount Baldy) but still a worthwhile outing with some great easy and moderate climbs. Relatively new (as of 2010) with very textured and grippy rock. Wear a helmet.
